metadata.case_name: Mangi Lal Joshi v. Krishnaji Rao Pawar

facts.text: Seat for Dewas Assembly Constituency No. 256 fell vacant due to death of Shri Hattesing, successful candidate in General Elections held in February 1967.
Bye-election held in June 1968 for Dewas Assembly Constituency No. 256.
Appellant Mangi Lal Joshi contested on Indian National Congress ticket; Respondent No.1 Krishnaji Rao Pawar contested as independent candidate and was elected.

Election petition filed by appellant under s.81 of Representation of the People Act challenging respondent's election on grounds of corrupt practices under s.123(4), excess expenditure under s.123(6), and disqualification under s.9A.

Public meeting held at Jawahar Chowk, Dewas at about 8 PM on June 13, 1968 in support of respondent's election, addressed by Abdul Rehman Talib, Kr. Virendrasingh, Kanhaiyasingh Thakur, and Khasherao Ghorpade.
Abdul Rehman Talib stated at meeting: 'No votes should be given to such Congress Candidate who has misappropriated the money'; also that a case was pending in court against appellant.

Kr. Virendrasingh's alleged statement: 'I have come from Labour Colony. Water tank is lying empty. All the money of water subscription has been misappropriated by Congress candidate INTUC, Mangilal Joshi. The workers will not vote for him.' Not proved by High Court.
Kanhaiyasingh Thakur stated at meeting: 'The workers subscription has been misappropriated by INTUC Joshi. There is also a case pending against him in Court.'
Khasherao Ghorpade stated at meeting: 'No votes be given to the corrupt candidate of Congress who has misappropriated workers subscription money.'
Respondent was present throughout the meeting on June 13, 1968.

Publication in weekly Ranchandi dated June 16, 1968: 'Voters beware of Joshi misappropriator of the workers subscription. Corrupt Congress candidate Mangilal Joshi. Appeal to remain careful of the misappropriator of mill workers subscription, corrupt candidate Mangilal Joshi.'

Criminal complaint dated July 27, 1965 filed by Lal Singh against appellant Mangi Lal Joshi (President of Dewas Mill Mazdoor Sangh) and Kanahiyalal (Secretary) under ss.403 and 406 IPC for misappropriating membership fees Rs.15,000, Wageboard Fund Rs.1,500, Gratuity Fund Rs.1,500, Mazdoor Sevadal Rs.900, Travelling Fund Rs.1,000, Water Tax Rs.1,000; most amounts not deposited or entered in registers.
Criminal case No.52 of 1965 pending at time of bye-election; charge framed on August 22, 1968.
Appellant admitted in cross-examination that criminal complaint of July 27, 1965 was filed against him and was pending during bye-election, charge framed August 22, 1968.
Respondent No.1 was Chairman of Board of Directors of Dewas Senior Electric Supply Company Private Limited, which supplied electricity to State Government under a contract.
Petrol worth about Rs.2,000 purchased by respondent between May 31, 1968 and June 15, 1968 from M/s A.J. Khanuja & Sons, Dewas.
Respondent admitted election expenses of Rs.6,576.78.
Respondent owned two jeeps, five cars, one tractor, one pick-up van, and 500 acres agricultural land; used jeeps for election but petrol also for household and agricultural purposes.
High Court dismissed election petition on March 27, 1970.

legal_issues.text: Whether there was corrupt practice under s.123(4) of the Act by publication of false statements relating to personal character and conduct of appellant at meeting on June 13, 1968 and in Ranchandi dated June 16, 1968.
Whether respondent was disqualified under s.9A of the Act due to subsisting contract with State Government as Chairman of Dewas Senior Electric Supply Company.
Whether respondent incurred election expenses in excess of prescribed limit under s.77 read with r.90, amounting to corrupt practice under s.123(6), particularly petrol purchases of Rs.2,000.

petitioner_arguments.text: Speakers at June 13 meeting and Ranchandi publication made false statements about appellant misappropriating workers' subscription money, believed to be false or not believed to be true by speakers and respondent.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.123(4) Representation of the People Act, 1951

petitioner_arguments.text: Respondent disqualified as Chairman of Electric Supply Company having contract with State for supply of electricity, which is supply of goods.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.9A Representation of the People Act, 1951

petitioner_arguments.text: Petrol worth Rs.2,000 purchased May 31 to June 15, 1968 must be added to admitted expenses of Rs.6,576.78, exceeding limit.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.77 and s.123(6) Representation of the People Act, 1951; r.90 Election Rules

respondent_arguments.text: Speakers only pointed out pending prosecution against appellant for embezzlement of Mazdoor Sangh funds; statements not made with consent; based on 1965 complaint.
No direct contract with Government; Company is separate entity; Chairman not engaged in trade or business.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.9A Representation of the People Act, 1951; Satya Prakash v. Bashir Ahmed Qureshi AIR 1963 MP 316

respondent_arguments.text: Petrol purchased for multiple vehicles used for household, agricultural, and election purposes; only marked items for election; not all Rs.2,000 for election.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.77 Representation of the People Act, 1951

respondent_arguments.text: Ranchandi editor published independently without respondent's consent; statements not believed false.

court_reasoning.text: Statements at meeting and in Ranchandi prima facie offend s.123(4) if false and believed false or not believed true, but appellant failed to prove falsity and belief; based on pending 1965 criminal complaint for misappropriation, charge framed post-election; statements bona fide.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Heavy burden on petitioner not discharged; complaint notorious fact, not conjecture.

court_reasoning.text: s.9A applies to contracts entered by person in course of his trade/business; Company separate entity; Chairman not personally contracting.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Supply of electricity by Company not Chairman's trade/business.

court_reasoning.text: No evidence connecting entire Rs.2,000 petrol to election; respondent had multiple vehicles for domestic/agricultural use; purchases in April 1968 Rs.2,604 indicate normal usage.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Petitioner failed to establish additional expenditure for election.

court_reasoning.text: Criminal complaint, charge order, Lal Singh's statement admissible under Evidence Act ss.7,8,11(2); appellant's admission supports.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant cannot challenge what he elicited.

holdings.text: No corrupt practice under s.123(4); statements not proved false or believed false/not believed true.
No disqualification under s.9A; Chairman of Company not personally having Government contract in trade/business.
No excess expenditure proved; no corrupt practice under s.123(6).

precedents_cited.relevance: False statements made bona fide protected under s.123(4).

precedents_cited.case_name: Dr. Jagjit Singh v. Giani Kartar Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Heavy burden on petitioner to prove statement false and believed false or not believed true under s.123(4).

precedents_cited.case_name: Satya Prakash v. Bashir Ahmed Qureshi
precedents_cited.relevance: Chairman of company not personally entering government contract under s.9A.

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for election petition, appeal, corrupt practices of false statements, excess expenditure, disqualification for government contracts.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Sections under which criminal complaint for misappropriation filed against appellant.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Admissibility of criminal complaint and statements.

statutes_cited.name: Conduct of Election Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Prescribed limit for election expenses with s.77.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding High Court's dismissal of election petition; all charges of corrupt practices and disqualification failed for lack of proof.

key_quotes.text: "the impugned statement was not founded on mere suspicion pure or simple nor was it the result of pure conjecture or guess. It had positive basis and the basis subsequently proved to be prima facie correct, therefore, the impugned statement falls within the ambit of bona fide statement."
key_quotes.speaker: lower_court
key_quotes.significance: High Court's reasoning on bona fides of statements under s.123(4), affirmed by Supreme Court.

key_quotes.text: "A Company registered under the Indian Companies Act... is a separate entity distinct from its shareholders. The Chairman... cannot be said to be engaged in his trade or business as contemplated by S.9A."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "there is a very heavy burden on the petitioner appellant to prove... that the impugned statement of fact is not only false, but... the respondent... either believed the same to be false or did not believe them to be true."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on burden of proof under s.123(4).
